settings.text:
• Noisy neighbors are no fun. They can make your home an unpleasant place to be – especially when you’re trying to relax or sleep. 
  • Depending on where the noise is coming from, there are a number of different ways to help block the noise coming from next door. 
  • Soundproofing your walls, floors and windows with art, rugs and curtains can help dampen noise levels. 
  • Earplugs are the perfect way to reduce the decibel level of noise from next door without any refurbishing or rearranging. Loop’s range of sleek and comfortable earplugs can reduce sound by up to 27 decibels.

Next-door neighbors always seem to be romanticized in TV and films. 

They’re the people you turn to for comfort, company or just a cup of sugar. They’re the community that your life is built around, a friendly hand on your shoulder that guides you through your troubles and woes. 

But in reality, they can often be a massive pain in the… 

Ears. 

It’s true – noisy neighbors are a complete and utter nightmare.

Fancy a nice relaxing day? 

They’re mowing the lawn. 

Want to catch an early night?

They’re having an all-night rave. 

Want to hear yourself think just once?

They’re having a huge argument about whose turn it is to clean the downstairs bathroom. 

What. A. Pain. 

But fear not. You don’t have to carry on like this. There are some tried-and-tested ways to reduce noise from your neighbors’ apartment or house that you can put into effect almost immediately. 

And they’re not only fast, simple and effective but pretty cheap too. 

So here are our top three tricks on how to block noise from your neighbors and finally get some well-deserved peace and quiet.
Give customers details about the banner image(s) or content on the template.

settings.heading: What happens if you don’t get enough sleep?

settings.text:
Did you know that the average person spends about one-third of their life sleeping? 

That’s a lot of hours. 

But sleep is absolutely essential to maintaining a healthy lifestyle. 

Without enough sleep, everything from your body to your mind can be affected. Your immune system and metabolism can suffer. Your cognitive functioning can become impaired, and you are more likely to experience mood swings, depression, and anxiety.

It’s fair to say that getting enough shut-eye each night is pretty important.

So if you want to stay happy and healthy, just hit the snooze button and sleep a bit longer, right? 

Unfortunately, life isn’t always that simple.

It’s a simple fact – the emptier a room is, the more noise will echo around it. 

Now we’re not saying you need to fill your room to the brim with everything and anything to keep those pesky neighbors from ruining your quiet night in, but a little bit of decorating can go a long way when it comes to sound absorption. 

Add some furniture such as a comfy armchair, a handy bookshelf or maybe that chaise longue you’ve had your eye on for a while. 

The more space that’s taken up in the room, the less room there is for sound to bounce around.

Ugh, what a pain. Your neighbors are noisy little so-and-so’s and now you’ve got to soundproof your house?

We’ll admit it’s not ideal. 

But a few hours of work certainly beats never relaxing or sleeping properly again, right? 

Now we’re not saying you need to go and completely change the architecture of your home. 

There’ll be no wrecking balls here, thank you very much. 

Instead, here’s how you can effectively give your house some DIY soundproofing without breaking the bank (or your house).

How to soundproof your walls?

While acoustic insulation paneling is the best option, it’s also the most expensive. So unless you’ve got a few thousand dollars spare (or the noisiest neighbors in the world), you can get a bit creative with your soundproofing instead. 

Try hanging some art or other decorative pieces on your walls for an extra bit of sound absorption. Maybe even a mood board or a whiteboard where you can write down your to-do lists or your goals. 

Goal 1: Get new neighbors…

How to soundproof your windows?

Do you ever hear a bunch of noise from outside, get up to close the windows and realize that they’re already shut and it’s just THAT loud? 

Devastating. 

Sometimes a closed window just isn’t enough to shut out the noise. Try checking to see if your window frames are properly sealed. You’ll not only be able to keep out some extra sound, but your heating bills will also thank you. 

If that doesn’t work then try hanging some heavy curtains for a bit of extra absorption. 

How to soundproof your floors?

Noisy downstairs neighbors? 

There’s a quick, easy, and comfy way to deaden noise from below – simply lay a nice thick rug on the floor. This will help to keep out intrusive sound, and will also improve the feng shui of your room.

settings.heading: 3. Invest in a good pair of earplugs

settings.text:
You’ve tried everything. 

You’ve rearranged your furniture, you’ve hung some art, you’ve laid some rugs, you’ve even tried taping four pillows around your ears with a whole reel of tape. 

And yet those nightmare neighbors are still causing your ears to break down and cry. 

Funnily enough, one of the best solutions is actually one of the easiest things you can do.

Get yourself a pair of good-quality earplugs. 

Loop’s Experience, Quiet, and Engage earplugs are designed to not only protect your hearing from high noise levels, but also to help you feel more comfortable in any environment – whether that’s in the front row of a raucous festival, or sitting on the sofa trying to ignore your neighbors wreaking havoc next door. 

Earplugs don’t simply block out noise, they work by reducing the decibel level of the environment you’re exposed to – helping you to live life at your own volume.

settings.heading: Don’t let noisy neighbors ruin your day

settings.text:
Being sensitive to noise is upsetting at the best of times. But your house is your home, it’s where you’re supposed to be safe, comfortable and relaxed – so don’t let anyone take that away from you. 

We hope these ways to reduce noise from your neighbors can give you some insight into how to make your life more comfortable. 

And remember, if your neighbors are cranking up the volume a bit too much, try talking to them. And if that doesn’t work, check your local noise laws – we bet they won’t make as much noise with a hefty fine in their letterbox! 

If you’re in desperate need of some immediate peace and quiet, Loop Quiet earplugs can make a huge difference as they reduce noise by up to 27 decibels.

Browse our selection today and find a solution that works for you.

settings.heading: What type of earplugs is the best for sleeping?

settings.text:
There are a number of things that you need to consider when deciding what type of earplugs to wear to improve your sleep. 

First off, they need to stay in. 

Some lower-quality earplugs aren’t designed well enough to fit in a typical ear canal. This means that every time you roll over in the night there’s a chance your earplugs will simply fall out. 

Secondly, your earplugs need to be comfortable. 

Comfort is key. Because after all, discomfort and sleep don’t exactly go hand in hand – and the comfier you are, the more likely you are to get a peaceful night’s sleep. 

And if your earplugs are uncomfortable, there’s a much higher chance that you will unconsciously remove them in your sleep – exposing your ears to the very noise that you were aiming to block out. 

And finally, you need your earplugs to block out noise effectively. 

There’s no point going through the hassle of researching, buying, and wearing earplugs if they don’t sufficiently block out the noise that’s keeping you awake. 

That’s why it’s imperative that you choose a pair that properly reduces noise levels in your immediate surroundings, giving you a nice, peaceful night’s sleep. 

Loop Quiet is the perfect solution that ticks all three boxes: function, comfort, and noise reduction.

Giving you up to 27 dB of noise reduction, Loop Quiet provides Loop’s highest level of decibel protection. These earplugs are perfect for shutting out the world so you can drift off in peace.

As for how to wear earplugs to sleep? Just pop them in and settle down. The noise reduction they provide will allow you to get the rest you need to start the next day feeling fresh and well rested.
Unfortunately, there is no quick and easy cure for being scared of loud noises. However, there are a number of ways that you can control and even reduce the effects of phonophobia.

Relaxation techniques

As phonophobia is often linked with issues such as anxiety and stress, sometimes the effects can be reduced by some simple relaxation techniques.

Meditation and yoga can go a long way toward giving you a sense of peace, calmness, and balance that can help subdue phonophobia, as well as improve your overall mental and physical health. 

The practice of meditation can help you to find your center and bring about some level of inner peace – making it a key tool when battling phobias.

Therapy

Like with any phobia, getting help from a professional is the best way toget a handle on your phonophobia.

Fortunately, there are a number of different types of therapy that have shown positive results when being used to treat phobias. Let’s take a look at the two most common:

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) 

Cognitive behavioral therapy, or CBT, is a type of psychotherapy that concentrates on recognizing negative or unhelpful patterns of behavior and thought. 

Known as a “talking therapy”, CBT can help you manage your issues by encouraging you to change the way that you handle certain situations. 

It’s commonly used to treat conditions such as depression and anxiety, but it has also proved to be very effective in treating several different types of phobias, such as phonophobia. 

The typical course of treatment for CBT consists of between six and 20, hour-long sessions. It is a treatment that concentrates on the here and now, rather than searching for a root cause in the past in the way that many other therapies do.

Exposure therapy

Exposure therapy, or systematic desensitization, is another type of psychotherapy that is regularly utilized when treating people with phonophobia.

It works by using guided and repeated exposure to the phobia in question in order to desensitize the patient. By being exposed to the source of the fear with no ill consequences, it is thought that exposure therapy can help the patient realize that their fear is unwarranted. 

While this type of therapy can be upsetting, it’s also proved to be extremely effective with high success rates. 

Don’t worry though – a therapist running an exposure therapy session will use a graded approach so that you’re not instantly overwhelmed. 

So for example, if you are afraid of mice, the therapist may start a session just by showing you a drawing of a mouse. Then upping the exposure level as you become more and more desensitized to the stimuli.

settings.heading: Earplugs and sleep: A dreamy match

settings.text:
A proper night’s sleep can make a world of difference to your everyday life. 

It can be the difference between having a good day and a dreadful one – so why leave anything to chance?

Earplugs are an effective and safe way to keep your energy up and your sleep habits healthy, and to make sure that you’re getting the sleep you need to thrive. 

Our Loop Quiet earplugs are perfect for sleep – and they’re our bestselling pair. Our other two sets – Experience and Engage – aren’t as good for sleeping, but are designed to not only protect your hearing, but also to help you navigate and feel confident in the wide world of sound. 

Whether you’re looking to fall asleep, stay asleep, or just get some peace and quiet, Loop’s got you covered.

settings.heading: Don’t let your phobia take control

settings.text:
Left unchecked, phonophobia is a condition that can truly affect your quality of life. 

But when tackled head-on, the condition is actually highly treatable, and handling it can become a simple part of your daily routine. 

There is no question that the best course of action is to seek help from a professional healthcare expert. A trained professional will be able to assess your condition, decide the best course of action, and then point you in the right direction of treatment. 

But if you want to be comfortable whilst you’re working toward overcoming your phobia, then earplugs such as Loop Engage can help guide you through your fear and make your day-to-day life more comfortable.

Because to truly live life at your own volume, you need to be the one in control of your destiny.
